comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: Wystan:  Thanks for bringing this to our attention--we'll look into this spelling discrepancy.

comment.author: 39123284@N07
comment._content:
You have NOT misspelled the name. This is Alois B. SALIGER, born about 1880 in the Adlergebirge area of Bohemia (Austria), immigrated about 1883. He grew up in the Lewis County, WA area. His parents were Frank and Marie Saliger.
I would guess that about the time that this picture was taken, Alois was living in New York City.
Alois was an inventor and businessman, owner of the Saliger Ship Salvage Company in New York.

comment.author: 68439219@N06
comment._content:
A. B. Salinger, in May 1911 ,at a hangar located at the Belmont Park Racetrack in New York, had a "headless" biplane (meaning no forward canards / elevating planes.) ( New York Herald May 1, 1911)
From Aeronautics magazine  July 1911  " A. B. Sallinger  ( sic) has a big headless biplane with a 100 hp Emerson engine, spreading 36 feet by 6.5 feet between planes.
